episode.title: Cities Service Gas Co. v. State Corporation Comm'n of Kan.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- 85, Cities Service Gas Company, a Corporation, Appellant, versus State Corporation Commission of Kansas, et al.
Mr. Rolston.

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: May it please the Court.
This case is here on appeal taken by appellant, Cities Service Gas Company, to reverse the final judgment of the Supreme Court of Kansas.

The judgment of that court sustained as valid, a gas price fixing order issued by the Corporation Commission of Kansas, fixing a minimum prize of 11 cents per Mcf on a 14.65 pressure base as applied to sales of gas made in the Kansas portion of the Hugoton Field to appellant for resale in Interstate Commerce.
These sales were wellhead sales made by producers in the field to appellant under long-term contracts which were substantially lower than the price fixed by the Kansas order.

There were also sales in the interstate commerce made by producers after the producer had completed gathering the gas, producing and gathering gas and sold it at the end of gathering in the field to the appellant, Cities Service Gas Company.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Those sales are involved in this case too?

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: Sales at the wellhead and those made at the end of gathering in the field.
The question before this Court, as stated by the appellant is just one single jurisdictional problem.

That question is can a state in the exercise of this gas conservation powers lawfully fix a minimum price for natural gas sold in interstate commerce resell in phase of the provisions of the Natural Gas Act giving the Federal Power Commission exclusive jurisdiction over the rates governing such sales.

You do not accept that the question presented is as stated in the appellees brief?

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: We do not, Your Honor, and we regret very much that we can't read the Kansas Supreme Court decision as the appellees have done.
And I shall discuss that matter more in detail.

turn.speaker: joe_rolston

turn.text: We don't.

turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: Insofar as fixing the price is concerned, as to sales in interstate commerce resale, we do.

turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter

turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston

We're making no contention in this case that in the absence of the provisions of the Natural Gas Act.
A state cannot constitutionally fix the minimum price for the natural gas.

As a matter of fact, this Court held that and that Cities Service Gas Company against Peerless Oil & Gas Company and Phillips Petroleum Company against State Corporation Commission and that we're not questioning that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You're not questioning --

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: We're not conceding though, Your Honor, that it's necessary to fix the price in order to conserve gas under the statute's conservation, statutes of Kansas or Oklahoma or any other states.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I just want to state out the precise question and you're not challenging how the State, to prevent ways and protect correlative rights, stated like that out to you.
But you say that this is a statutory question -- a question statutory construction whether this power has the rate has been withdrawn by the Natural Gas Act.

turn.speaker: joe_rolston

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that's all.

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: That's the only question that we have before this Court.
But we do not want to be construe their saying that we think it's necessary to fix price in order to conserve gas.
There's adequate machinery under the many state enactments governing that phase of conservation which we think are adequate.

Before discussing the -- the material portion, the order involved in this lawsuit, I think maybe it would be helpful for this Court to know that this price fixing feature is -- is nothing new back in 1947.
The State of Oklahoma fixed a seven-cent price for gas produced and sold in the Oklahoma portion of the Hugoton Field.
In 1948 after the Oklahoma procedure had taken place, the Kansas Commission fixed an eight-cent price for natural gas produce and sold in the Kansas portion of the Hugoton Field.
Then in 1952, the Oklahoma Commission each within new order in which they fixed the price at 9.8262.

Then in 1954, effective January 1st, 1954, the Kansas Commission issued this order, fixing 11-cent price and changing the pressure base which constitutes approximately a 12-cent price with the change in the pressure base.
Now, I want to quote a small portion of the -- of the order that's under consideration because it to me is self-explanatory and I think directly answers Mr. Justice Frankfurter's question.

Here's what they say, it's on page 45 of the record, the order says this that all persons, firms or corporations which take gas or cost a gas to be taken from Hugoton gas field in Kansas on and after January 1st, 1954, 12:01 a.m. shall as a condition present or withdraw from the common source of supply pay or attribute to all gas taken, except gas for the operation of leases for all purposes including payments to producers, landowners, lease owners and royalty owners the fair and the reasonable minimum price of not less than 11 cents per Mcf, 14.65 pounds psi at the wellhead until a further order of this Commission.
Now, the portion of the order that answers the question is that says -- part which says for all purposes including payments to producers.
Now, it starts out that all persons, firms or corporations which take or cost gas to be taken.
We certainly take gas from the field because we have a pipeline in the field.

And if the Court will turn to Exhibit 34 at page 79 of the record, the Court will find set for a complete map of the pipeline system of Cities Service Gas Company showing its gas fields from which it takes its gas or purchase its gas and it shows the vast Hugoton Field there and the Panhandle Field in Texas and some other fields in Oklahoma and Kansas.
The Court will observe that this Hugoton gas field which the Commission has said and I think we can agree as the largest gas field in the world, lies on three states, Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas.
Now, as I made the point at the start, we are not contesting or claiming.
The state does not have any power to fix a minimum price for natural gas produced and sold in interstate commerce as against constitutional objections.

But when you bring in the provisions of the Natural Gas Act, which this Court considered in the case of Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America v. Panoma Corporation and some other cases in a per curiam opinion, 349 U.S. 44 and Phillips Petroleum Company v. State of Wisconsin et al. in 347 U.S. 672.

It is our contention than as to any sale of gas made in any -- in interstate commerce for resale that this Court has held by the Phillips case and the Panoma case and as reinforced by the plain language of the Natural Gas Act which in Section 1 (b) says that the Act shall apply to the sale in interstate commerce of natural gas for resale and the Natural Gas Company is engaged in such sale.
Now --

But may I have a little bit of (Inaudible)
Did you tell Justice Black just now that all gas you purchased is in interstate commerce?

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: No, I -- I didn't say that.
I -- I think that's correct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: All?

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: That all the gas that we purchased goes in into our interstate pipeline system.
And the record shows that it's commingled with gas from three other common sources of supply, some in Kansas, some in Oklahoma and some in Texas.
Now, the -- the commingled gas according to one of our witnesses and that wasn't disputed.
He -- he said you couldn't identify the gas to mark it in of the pipeline.
But he estimated that 48% of the Kansas gas in the Kansas Hugoton Field was sold intrastate and the balance of it was sold outside the State.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: By all the gas from this field?

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: No, we get 31% of our total gas supplies from this Kansas portion of the Hugoton Field and -- and most all or -- or substantial part, most all of our gas, well I'd say half of it estimating, comes from the Kansas Hugoton and Oklahoma portion of the Hugoton Field.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Tell me whether I misunderstood you as I talked to you erroneously from my looking at the (Inaudible)
In 1951, 55% and 47% of the gas you purchase in the Hugoton Field were purchased to wellhead.

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: 44% and 67% is purchased after production and gathering.
And that the total 51.5% is sold in commerce so the rest is sold in the State of Kansas.

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: Well, 48%, that's merely an estimate, 48% of the gas because its commingled gas and we can't identify it, Mr. Justice Whittaker and it's only an estimate of the witness.
When the gas is taken and commingled from these different sources of supply, there's no way in the world to identify which gas comes from which field.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Which goes to which place?

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is there a definite proportion though?
I think a gas -- you can call it fungible goods.
Is there a definite proportion that is intrastate commerce and interest to that too that you object to this order?

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: The only answer I can make to that, Mr. Justice Frankfurter, is that there is some of this gas sold and offers the pipe -- interstate pipeline that comes from the Kansas -- portion of Hugoton Field in Kansas.
There is some.
It isn't a large amount to get.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, is Kansas defending this order on the ground that this is regulating the price of gas sold in Kansas?
Is Kansas defending on that ground?
Kansas is saying we're merely fixing intrastate rates on intrastate transactions --

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: No, no, they're -- they are saying that this is a conservation measure.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I understand that.
I just want to know whether that is an issue here that this is in fact --

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: No, there -- there --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- a regulation of intrastate sales in Kansas.

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: There -- there -- if that was correct and -- and the Court has held, we wouldn't be up here because it wouldn't affect that hardly [Laughs] but they --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The State Commission hasn't held that yet, has it?
They wanted to raise the price of Kansas but not in -- for Kansas consumers but not for out of state consumers.

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: Well, the -- the -- you see, you've got these price orders.
You had them up in the Panoma case and -- and there's no difference in any of them.
There is no difference in the price order in this case and the Panoma case except the price.
And as I understand the position of the appellees in this case, we asked them to tell us whether we are required to pay this price before the Supreme Court of Kansas and they didn't tell us.
And I -- and I think they ought to tell this Court whether or not the producer is -- is required to get -- this gas goes in the interstate commerce price.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: As I understand your answer to Mr. Justice Frankfurter that the State of Kansas is making no question about the fact that part of the gas is sold locally in Kansas.

They -- they attack it -- the whole of the sale -- all the gas on the same basis, namely, that they have a power in conservation to regulate the price at the wellhead and before you get it, is that right?

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: Well, I don't know as I understand your question, Mr. Justice Whittaker.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, if -- who does the mixing of this gas?
You do it, do you not?

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: In your own line.

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: We operate our own --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: There was a time when at the wellhead when it wasn't commingled with other gas destined for commerce, isn't that true?

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, then --

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: Yes.
Now, wait just a minute.
Any gas under the decisions I read in this Court, (Inaudible) Walker Miller Company owned them that if the gas is destined for outstate consumption that is the substantial portion.
It doesn't make any difference about the intrastate state.
There is the decision I think of this (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, is Kansas making any contention that to that effect here that there should be -- that your attempt to hereby mixing the gas in your pipelines with other gas and some of it sold by you for local use in Kansas, do they claim that makes a difference?

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: They -- they said nothing in their briefs.
I heard them say nothing in their oral arguments and the Court said nothing in its opinions.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you have any other cases except the ones you'd cited?

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: Mr. Justice Black --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They -- they cover your case pretty well.

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: We -- we think --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: From your standpoint.

turn.speaker: joe_rolston
turn.label: Mr. Joe Rolston
turn.text: That's right.
And -- and we think that a fair reading of this Kansas Court's opinion is that they require their propriety and they require to produce here to be (Inaudible).
Now, if that is not correct, Your Honor, the Supreme Court of Kansas should say, You're not hurt and you know we don't care, but they wouldn't tell us.

And when you examine their other opinions in connection with this one, there isn't any question what in my mind of what they have said that we're required to pay and it applies to these sales in interstate commerce for resale.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: May it please the Court.
The Federal Power Commission is here asking that this decision be reversed and the Court hold that the order is invalid.
As far as we can find in the case, there is no issue that the State of Kansas has any right to regulate by an order of this type because this is gas moving only intrastate.
It's the question of whether because it is a conservation measure they have the right to regulate the price of the gas under the exemption of Section 1 (b) in regard to production and gathering.
It is just that simple.
Now, we have been troubled with the statement that this attributes a price rather than requires the payment of the price, but the order doesn't limit to attribute but requires payment or attribution.
But if you'll watch the order closely, you will note that the Kansas Court, in interpreting the order and the order itself, provides that the payment shall be made if it passes the wellhead.
It doesn't say that this is a charge for bringing this gas up to the Wellhead and no farther.
But if it passes the wellhead which gets it into a sale in interstate commerce then there is an attribution or payment to be made.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What do you think attribution means with it.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, I think it could mean, you just mark it up on your books and nobody paying more attention to it.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Or that you included in your -- any future price in the sale of gas?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: But they have -- that's the way it's been worked and Magnolia filed a filing before the Federal Power Commission in which they did include it in the price that they asked this -- this particular appellant to pay for the gas and the appellant proceeded to ask the Federal Power Commission or make a filing saying that it was entitled to an increase because of that.
So we find that by that kind of -- of a measure and the practical application by the parties which I think is impossible to avoid.
We get down to place where the poor consumer down at end doesn't get much benefit from the regulation by the Federal Power Commission.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What difference does it make whether you call it a sale and -- or an attribution if in terms of cents, there is compulsory requirement by the Kansas authority?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, there is no difference.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And therefore, the question gets back whatever word you use, the characterization you make whether that kind of compulsion can be exerted by Kansas, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That is -- that is correct.
And the importance --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Isn't that to fuss around whether it's an attribution or -- or a sale?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't mean --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The Kansas --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What I mean, what is the -- what's the legal significance of -- of fussing about that?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: It's one way of trying to get away from Panoma and Phillips that you can claim that there is an attribution and yet there's not a sale.
But the parties proceed to say, You've got to pay for the gas on this basis.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But the attribution is by governmental authority, isn't it?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And so the question comes back as to the power of the governmental authority.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: And if the Government can require that, the effect of it is to make the payment.
And in effect, it changes the price structure and immediately has already had that effect.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The only thing that I can see, in my limited way is if the party for some reason of unrelated to the thing want to conceal the real financial cost or payment and the State says, Oh no you can't conceal this for whatever the reason may be, tax reasons or I don't know what.
I can see that but there is no such suggestion here that this is a means of Kansas by which Kansas reaps some false faade from the transaction, gives it its true name.
It's Kansas that's doing something, isn't it?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

And the whole purpose of the conservation measure, that is what is to be called and that's the only way that it could be given any validity at all, would be to lift the price and the whole -- all of the records shows that in order to have some effect on purchases at the end with the idea that if we lift the prices up then it will get certain uses of gas out of the market for this particular gas.
Now, it isn't any kind of a conservation order at all if somebody doesn't have to pay it because nobody will notice any effect of it.

But the moment you put -- make somebody pay it, the man down the line that's use -- using it for what they consider uneconomic use or one that this gas shouldn't be used for because coal or oil or some other fuels should be used then he'll look it over and he'll say, Well that cost me too much.
Not somebody attributes something so I don't have to pay it, so what's the difference.
But he'll say, It cost me too much for this use and I'll quit using it.
That's the whole theory of the whole record but you can't deal with Panoma and Phillips as easily if you use it as frankly and openly as that.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: If Kansas had said, You can't take more than so much gas out of the field, would you quarrel with that?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, we wouldn't, no.
They are doing that very thing.
There's unitization --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You said they can't do it by fixing the price.
They could do it directly.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

I want to make that clear as -- as far as the Federal Power Commission is concerned in the Government brief by attorneys general of a number of the states had been filed here saying that, We are trying to extend this Act on behalf of the Federal Power Commission that we are claiming that the States have no power to regulate and we're intruding on that because of the statement that we used that there'll be a substantial effect on interstate commerce.

If you recall, that's the exact language of the Court used in Phillips when it said that there would be a substantial effect on interstate commerce by reason of this -- the price of these sales and so we used that same language.
Now, I want to make it clear.
There wasn't any purpose or intention.
There isn't any purpose or intention on the -- on the part of Federal Power Commission or the government to interfere with proper measures of conservation that the States are to regulate.

And this Court has recognized that they have that power but they can't handle conservation by regulating price because the moment they do, they come in to headlong conflict with the Federal Power Commission.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor, before we let go with our comment, your quick accession with Justice Harlan's suggestion, it might bottle up the oil, Kansas might bottle up the oil.
I just want to (Inaudible) that one would have to consider, Pennsylvania against West Virginia before you do that.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, as -- that's what bother --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not saying -- I'm saying it isn't so.
All I'm saying is, I just have (Inaudible) in the light of that decision.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's what bothered me about answering a question categorically that they could, as long as it's a regulation in degree.
It seems to me there is no question of what and a reasonably -- reasonable regulation that they can have conservation in that manner.
The thing that bothered me was whether the question included not allowing any gas to be transferred in the interstate commerce and then I think we have to have a reservation.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, wouldn't it be possible out in that Hugoton Field for people, owners of leases or owners of -- landlord's interest in leases to waste the gas just -- you've seen it bearing yourself out there.
Now, wouldn't the -- the State of Kansas have power you say, you want to waste it, you're going to have to pay 11 cents, a thousand for it?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, I think (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- when commerce is not involved.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I think there's a possibility and probability that they could do that but they do even more than that.
They prohibit the wasting of the gas as a conservation measure.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, could -- are they limited to doing that in one way?
Could they not also fortify that by requiring the payment of money if you do?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I don't see how there'd be any commerce involved then --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: No.
It wouldn't be --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- so we wouldn't have any problem of interference or clash under the Commerce Clause.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But does -- but -- that's just the point.
Is commerce involved when the gas is two feet below the surface of the ground and still in the pipes?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: But that is --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Is that in Commerce?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No.
But (Voice Overlap) -- that isn't what the order provides.
It doesn't say you can bring it up to the -- to the wellhead and you have to pay anything.
It says, If you bring it beyond, and there you got the commerce.
Now, we also do not claim --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, now have you.
You bring it one foot beyond the valve, within your own pipes and then send it on and off to your own factory which is located half a mile away, is commerce involved?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, this Court has held that where there's the sale --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: In commerce.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- wholesale for interstate commerce and there's transmission, there is a commingling that you cannot separate and that that gas is on its movement at least when it leaves the wellhead.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Sure.

All whole -- for example, all wholesales of natural gas, Phillips case now, in interstate commerce whether by pipeline company or not and whether occurring before, during or after transmission by an interstate pipeline company, of course is in commerce.
But is the principle different than commingling wheat that you own and I own and I tortuously commingle it.
And then I sell it in -- in commerce until that's -- am I then able to say that is all to be regulated as -- by federal power to the exclusion of the states?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, if you mean price regulation.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The Congress has said that the interstate sales or wholesale are regulated by the Federal Power Commission.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Yours but -- have you got an interstate sale until at least it's been commingled in interstate pipes.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, it is commingled when it leaves the Wellhead.

There isn't any question under the evidence in this case that when it leaves the wellhead here, it is commingled with gas that's sold in interstate commerce and in such a manner that it can't be possibly be separated by any man.
He cannot distinguish what part of the gas would go in the Intrastate Commerce and which will go in interstate commerce.

So, they're trying to reach, not the production of this gas up to the wellhead in which case, it wouldn't make any difference to any of these producers whether you attribute it or what you -- what -- what kind of a price you put on.

But it's that transfer beyond the wellhead that they are trying to fix the price on and it's that point at which it -- interstate commerce is subject to the control of the Natural Gas Act and the Federal Power Commission, that's our position.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does the State attack the State Supreme Court finding that this was in commerce and was sold by resale in interstate commerce?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: We don't find anything for that character in the issues --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has that been in dispute up today?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No.
Now, we also want to make clear that we do not contend that the States do not have a proper area of action as to reasonable taxation, severance tax and so forth.
It's asserted that we -- we may be moving and try to take that from them.
And of course, we recognized that the Natural Gas Act expressly had in mind that and as long as it comes within the requirements of the Calvert case.
We've seen no difficulty about those taxes and we're not contending that they are not properly entitled to.
Now, in examining Exhibits 35 and 36 on pages 80 and 81, it's very interesting to note by those exhibits just who's being affected by this kind of an order.
What -- who are the beneficiaries of raising this price up at the wellhead or after the production and gathering had been completed.
Both are involved in this case.
There are major gas companies.
They are not just a lot of little producers, Stanolind Oil & Gas Company for 26 million thousand cubic feet.
There is a small lot of jointly own wells there, 204,471.

Then we get down to Magnolia Petroleum Company, one of the majors, United Producing Company, Columbian Fuel Corporation, Western Natural Gas, Carbon Texas Company and Columbia, all substantial operators in the field that are going to be benefited by this kind of an operation of price fixing.
Now, it's suggested that the Federal Power Commission has recognized these rates and therefore has no right to object this time.
I want to tell the Court about that.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Could it -- could it by recognizing your way with the jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No, it could not.
But furthermore, it -- it has not and it has tried not to.
I'll put it that way and try to describe what has happened.

As you know the Act provides for filings and these three and half years since Phillips, they have been engulfed with filings by different producers over the country, some 19,000 better than 19,000 different filings.

Now, the Act doesn't say just because a man or producer files a paper in which he describes a certain rate which they were directed to do under the Federal Power Commission's order 174 that that -- the filing of it makes the Federal Power Commission's failure to do anything at that point an approval of it.
The Federal Power Commission must act within 30 days under Section 4, if it wants to suspend it.
It can come in under Section 5 (a) at anytime and examine into the rate and it can -- and that mere filing doesn't involve any affirmative action by the Federal Power Commission.
On this situation, there were two cases that I want to briefly describe to the Court.

One is the Magnolia case in which there was an application as described in the footnote to our brief for -- of price-wise because of this Kansas order and there was also the application of Cities Service.

When that application was first filed, it included the contract between the parties and the minimal price order and also the agreement that Cities Service have made whereby the producers that got this higher price because of this minimum price order would have to refund it to Cities Service if it was later declared illegal.
And the Commission first made it subject to that provision and then later, they eliminated that part.

The explanation I was given by the Federal Power Commission was that the elimination of it being subject to this provision of refund, if the courts would hold it illegal, was to not interfere with the court action and the court determination as to what the effect of this minimum price order would be and that case is not final.
It's now on appeal to the Tenth Circuit so that the Court can determine what the legal effect of this minimum price order is in regard to these contracts.
Now, we're talking about a sum of $4 million increase on the price of gas in this very case so that it is a -- a very substantial sum.
And you and I know that it isn't going to be paid down the bottom of the line to the producer without coming out the end here from the consumer.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What do you mean by $4 million increase?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That is the amount that's involved, the total amount that's involved between the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Over what period of time?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: One year, between the contracts and the minimum price.
Now --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is that just for this one company or --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: One company.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: There are others?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: There are others and there are a great number.
And I was trying to find out what the effect of this might be, this minimum price order on whole gas industry.
And it's quite clear that it reaches then to almost every pipeline that supplies important areas in this country.
The --

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: There's no argument about the impact of this order.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May -- may I ask you to turn to the order of the Commission.
I haven't read their interpreted order.
But would any interpretation change what need for me to -- to be plain on XXVIII in the jurisdictional statement where I got my order of the Commission just for convenience (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: I know.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Paragraph 17, that's the finding, isn't it?

That's the finding of the Commission by the premises finds, paragraph 17, finding 17 that curbs the fair and reasonable minimum price for gas that the wellhead in the Hugoton Field is 11 cents, then goes -- that's the finding.
That's -- they interpret that to mean anything of the cost -- that the wellhead price of gas is a fair price of 11 cents?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: Yes --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that subject to any other meaning on what it said?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: Unless you would argue about whether price meant value there, I think that's what it means.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right, I don't care what that means.
Well, anyhow, that's what -- it says somebody who wants gas they have to pay 11 cents today, is that right?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: I -- I think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Does it mean that even?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Does it mean that that if you want the -- the fair price at the wellhead is 11 cents.
I have great respect for ingenuity of the mind.
Tell me what it can mean other than what it says?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: I think it means that -- that it has a fair and reasonable value of what -- 11 cents at the wellhead.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Just as an abstract proposition.
Well then if it -- it implements that, then we go to the order in page 29.
It is further ordered by the Commission.

It's furthered by the Commission order that all person, firm or corporations which take gas or cause gas to be taken from the Hugoton Gas Field in Kansas, shall -- certainly, the -- the Cities Service cost to be taken in the sense that --

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: No, it does not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: The Commission has interpreted this order and the Supreme Court has interpret --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, let -- let me finish this one before we get to -- before you get to it -- shall as the condition precedent for withdrawal from the common source of supply, pay or attribute to all gas taken, except gas for the operation of leases at the wellhead until the further order is 11 cents.
Now, the Cities Service doesn't come in to the wellhead where it intervened in this whole process or chain of transaction, was at the wellhead, wasn't it?
Didn't -- when the Cities Service come in contact with the gas we're talking about at the wellhead, isn't it?
Did it have anything to do with this gas before the wellhead?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that's the well that it turns up and it wants the gas that's in there.

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And how can it get that gas?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: It can purchase it from the producer.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, can I get it any other way except having somebody who has control and hand it over to it.

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And when it's handed over to the Cities Service because that's the 11 cents, is that correct?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And it has to do so because the Commission has ordered it that it can't get it for less.

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: It -- state action requires the seller to attribute the value to it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right, attribute but Cities Service has to pay that 11 cents because Kansas has attributed 11 cents worth to that gas.

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: The seller can -- can sell it to somebody else from more 11 cents.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But it can't get it less than 11 cents --

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- to anybody, can he?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: No, that's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that whatever is -- whatever gas is involved that's between Cities Service and the seller is gas at the wellhead after all the physical transactions are completed and he can get that gas only if he can turn over 11 cents, is that right?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that gas when it goes over the Cities Services by ordinary customer channeled going in and outside of Kansas, is that correct too?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: After Cities Service purchases the gas.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But at that transaction, right there at the wellhead is what Cities Services is here about and what Kansas says you can't get -- put on it any other phase of transaction or monetary relationship except if you want it, you've got to pay at least 11 cents.

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: If Kansas does not tell that to Cities Service.
Kansas tells Magnolia.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Tells Magnolia.

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That you can't sell it the Cities Service less than 11 cents, is that right?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: If that's all you're going to do with it is sell it to Cities Service for 11 -- for less than 11 cents you can't produce --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But in fact, it sells it to a person who as a matter of vast range of business as interstate outlet for the gas he's getting, is that correct too?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: If it sells it to the Cities Service, it sells it to such a person.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose Magnolia buy or sells it for less than that, what can it be done to -- under Kansas law --

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: Well it --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- if it's a valid law.

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: The order says that they shall not take it out.
So it would be --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What sanction (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: -- from taking gas.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What sanction does your law provide for one who violates an order of your Commission?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: Well, I -- there are some single provisions I suppose --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It's a criminal provision (Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: For violation of an order?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: Well, the way the Kansas Commission has entered in this case is by so cost.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does the -- is it a violation of your criminal statute?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: No, no, I'm sure that's true.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: That's -- let's say Corporation Commission of Kansas.
The obvious method of enforcing this order was to -- would be to prevent them from taking the gas out of the field.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You could enjoin it from violating this order, couldn't you?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And what -- are you really -- the colloquy between you and me get down to this that Kansas has done nothing to Cities Service, doesn't know Cities Service, doesn't care about Cities Service, but Magnolia -- and Magnolia is free not to tell to anybody to oblige, is that right?
As far as this order is concerned, Magnolia didn't sell to anybody, is that right?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: As far as the order is concerned --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: -- that's -- that's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Magnolia -- but if it sell, it sell -- it must sell at 11 -- for 11 cents or attribute 11 cents, is that right?

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: Yes, that's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And Kansas doesn't know the existence of Cities Service, is that right?
Therefore, Cities Service is not involved.
Magnolia is free as a bird.
Therefore, nothing has happened.

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: Well, I -- I think you over simplify and overstate my position there.
I want to point out that this order was made to correct the continued monopolistic practices of the few pipeline companies out in the Kansas Hugoton Field.

And it was designed to correct correlative rights out there and that the price of gas in the Kansas Hugoton Field and the -- the conditions under which gas is produced in the Kansas Hugoton Field resulted from economic conditions peculiar to that field where a large number of small producers and landowners were facing drainage by reason of the monopolistic practices of the pipelines.
The -- there was a destructive competition among the small producers in trying to secure these pipeline connections.
And gas became a distress commodity and it was treated as a value -- a virtually valueless commodity.
It was blown in to air.

It was -- the wells were -- after the completion of the wells, they were -- they were blown for completion purposes carbon black plants sprang up in the area, manufacturing suit and using only about 92 or 9% or 10% of the energy of the gas.
In -- in short, a particle use and waste of this irreplaceable natural resource came into being.
And the evidence show that -- that there was a real relationship between treating this gas as a valueless or virtually valueless commodity and these wastes.
The record shows how this happened.
There were various wildcatters and the independents who first discovered the field.
There were just a few pipelines in the area.
It wasn't economically feasible to market this gas or to build a pipeline to market gas even from the largest wells or the 10 largest wells in the field.
You can't carry gas in the bucket like cooking oil.
You can't transport it from the truck.
You can't put it on a rail.
There's only one way to get it there and that's through pipelines.
And these pipelines constituted monopolies out there and the small independents and the producers were captive suppliers.
And they fought for connections and they lost some leases trying to get connections.
It cost about $25 to $30 million to build a pipeline.

And these pipeline companies, instead of giving the connections, and this is all in the record, instead of giving them connections, it would buy a lease right next to their leases and they drain their gas up from under them.
And so these independent producers, they wouldn't buy their gas.
They refuse to buy their gas.
Well, I'll have to continue this --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Finish that in the morning.

turn.speaker: dale_m_stucky
turn.label: Mr. Dale M. Stucky
turn.text: -- in the morning.
